> >A third way in to the puzzle: information is not useful until it i=
s
> >integrated into a framework of meaning. At any given time, any such

>framework has a loose boundary (the so-called hermeneutic horizon),

ch represents the only possible locations where new information can

it. If the boundary is not situated where the new information can

 in, it will be ignored, hence useless. So it pays to focus

come what it wants.
